transcription: San Pasqual Academy is a four-year residential high school for foster teens. It's the first of its kind in the nation. Nothing like this has ever been done before. San Pasqual is a licensed group home.  but it is not run as a group home, it is a boarding school and as such is a significant departure from existing group homes that we run in this country for foster kids. Judge Milliken is an absolutely remarkable man. He saw the true need of the foster teens. He saw what he felt was so critical to the future of our foster teens and he went for it.  The average foster care student has lived in at least a half a dozen different placements. Many who we interview for San Pasqual have been in 15 or 20. And as a result, every time they take a chance on somebody and form a relationship, they end up losing it. So the academy represents a place where they can stay home, make solid relationships with adults who care, whether they be teachers in the classroom, house parents  This is in the cottages. We've got an entire community here that spans all ages. So this place represents a home like no other place has been able to represent a home. I've been in the system for probably eight years now. And I've been in probably seven different foster homes and two different group homes. And it's just nice to know that once I got here, I knew that I was going to be here for a while. It makes it easier to be friends. And I don't think that, oh, they're not going to be here next week.  have any relationships and I'm able to make relationships knowing that I'm going to be here for two more years and be able to have those friendships, keep going and keep going, and that makes me feel stronger too. The comprehensive focus addresses the need of the whole child because it allows each member, collaborative member, to make sure that we're meeting the necessary needs to prepare these youth for adulthood. The partnerships that we have on campus is New Alternatives Incorporated, Health and Human Services,  which is called HHSA, the County Board of Education. And then the fourth partnership on the campus is called Workforce Partnership. And because nothing like this has really been done before, they want to make sure that it's done right. And in doing that, you've got to meet the needs of the students. The wonderful donors giving their financial support, giving their time and energy and their mentoring support is  absolutely crucial to the success of this whole campus. The Friends of San Francisco Academy have just been a remarkable team that has truly put their arms around the kids. We'd like to think that what we provide for our own child, we want to provide the same or much more for each and every one of these students.
